details.title: Parametric inference of incomplete data with competing risks among several groups
details.standardTitle: Parametric inference of incomplete data with competing risks among several groups

p: Chanseok Park is an Assistant Professor of Mathematical Sciences at Clemson University, Clemson, SC. He received his B.S. in Mechanical Engineering from Seoul National University; his M.A. in Mathematics from the University of Texas at Austin; and his Ph.D. in Statistics in 2000 from the Pennsylvania State University. His research interests include survival analysis, competing risks, statistical inference using quadratic inference function, robust inference, and statistical computing and simulation.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math. Sci., Clemson Univ., SC, USA
authors.name: C. Park

p: K. B. Kulasekera is a Professor of Mathematical Sciences at Clemson University. He received his B.S. in 1979 from the University of Sri Lanka; his M.A. in Statistics from the University of New Brunswick; and his Ph.D. in Statistics from the University of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE. His research interests include survival analysis, nonparametric regression, and multivariate methods.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math. Sci., Clemson Univ., SC, USA
authors.name: K.B. Kulasekera

details.abstract: We develop parametric inferential methods for the competing risks problem where data arise due to multiple causes of failure in several groups with censoring and possibly missing causes. We provide the general likelihood method and the closed-form maximum-likelihood estimators for the exponential model. Parametric tests are given for comparing different causes and groups. An extensive numerical and graphical investigation is presented to substantiate the proposed methods. A real-data example is illustrated.

citations.title: Parametric inference of incomplete data with competing risks among several groups

context.text: The traditional approach when dealing with competing risks is to consider the hypothetical latent lifetimes corresponding to each cause in the absence of the others [1].

references.title: Life tests under competing causes of failure and the theory of competing risks
references.text: M. L. Moeshberger, H. A. David, "Life tests under competing causes of failure and the theory of competing risks", Biometrics, vol. 27, pp. 909-933, 1971.

context.text: The analysis of exponential data with two causes in a single group was studied by Cox [2]; and was extended to multiple causes by Herman and Patell [3].

references.title: The analysis of exponentially distributed lifetimes with two types of failures
references.text: D. R. Cox, "The analysis of exponentially distributed lifetimes with two types of failures", J. Royal Stat. Soc. B, vol. 21, pp. 411-421, 1959.

context.text: The analysis of exponential data with two causes in a single group was studied by Cox [2]; and was extended to multiple causes by Herman and Patell [3].

references.title: Maximum likelihood estimation for multi-risk model
references.text: R. J. Herman, R. K. N. Patell, "Maximum likelihood estimation for multi-risk model", Technometrics, vol. 13, pp. 385-396, 1971.

links.abstract: Parametric and nonparametric estimation methods are proposed for reliability characteristics of one failure mode under competing risks with incomplete data; some of the failure times are observed without observing the cause of failure. The efficiencies of these methods are discussed.

context.text: The parametric estimation problem for the case of a single group with two causes and possible missing causes but without censoring has been discussed by Miyakawa [4].

references.title: Analysis of incomplete data in competing risks model
references.text: M. Miyakawa, "Analysis of incomplete data in competing risks model", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 33, pp. 293-296, 1984.

context.text: Kundu and Basu [5] extended this work to provide the approximate and asymptotic properties of the parameter estimators, \$s\$-confidence intervals, and bootstrap \$s\$-confidence bounds.
The proposed estimators include the estimators given by Kundu and Basu [5] as a special case.

references.title: Analysis of incomplete data in presence of competing risks
references.text: D. Kundu, S. Basu, "Analysis of incomplete data in presence of competing risks", J. Statistical Planning and Inference, vol. 87, pp. 221-239, 2000.

context.text: An alternative to the traditional latent lifetime framework is the parametric mixture-model approach adopted by Larson and Dinse [6].

references.title: A mixture model for the regression analysis of competing risks data
references.text: M. G. Larson, G. E. Dinse, "A mixture model for the regression analysis of competing risks data", Appl. Stat., vol. 34, pp. 201-211, 1985.

context.text: Recently, Maller and Zhou [7] extended this model to allow the possibility that the competing risks considered may not be exhaustive.

references.title: Analysis of parametric models for competing risks
references.text: R. A. Maller, X. Zhou, "Analysis of parametric models for competing risks", Statistica Sinica, vol. 12, pp. 725-750, 2002.

context.text: Gray [8] proposed a class of \$k\$-sample tests for comparing the CIF between \$k\$ groups for a given cause.

references.text: R. J. Gray, " A class of \$k\$ -sample tests for comparing the cumulative incidence of a competing risk ", Annals of Statistics, vol. 16, pp. 1140-1154, 1988.

context.text: Aly [9] proposed tests for testing the equality of two CSHF with censoring.

references.text: E.-E. A. A. Aly, S. C. Kochar, I. W. McKeague, "Some tests for comparing cumulative incidence functions and cause-specific hazard rates", J. Amer. Stat. Association, vol. 89, pp. 994-999, 1994.

links.abstract: A competing-risks model refers to a situation where a system (or organism) is exposed to two or more causes of failure (or death) but its eventual failure (or death) can be attributed to exactly one of the causes of failure. The basic information available in the competing-risks situation is the time to failure of the system, and the corresponding cause of failure. In practice, the causes of failure are often statistically dependent (the latent failure time of an individual failing from one caus...

context.text: Lam [11] tests whether the CSHF are the same when there are \$s\$-dependence between multiple causes.
